item.title: Draft Epstein Indictment Accused Him of Crimes Against More Than a Dozen Girls
item.description: Jeffrey Epstein, who ended up pleading to a much lesser state charge, told one victim that bad things could happen to her if she talked, the 2007 document said.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: In 2019, the F.B.I. announced new sex trafficking charges against Jeffrey Epstein, the disgraced financier.

item.title: ‘Melania’ Review: 20 Stage-Managed Days in the Life of the First Lady
item.description: Directed by Brett Ratner, the documentary shows a woman deeply concerned with her appearance who rarely lets us behind her facade.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Trump Officials Bypass Congress to Push Billions in Weapons Aid to Israel
item.description: The move was the third time the Trump administration has tried to expedite arms shipments to Israel by going around the review process for weapons sales.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Gonzalo Fuentes/Reuters
item.media:description: The weapons aid included Apache attack helicopters and combat land vehicles.

item.title: Release of Three Million Epstein Pages Falls Short, Survivors Say
item.description: Todd Blanche, the deputy attorney general, told reporters on Friday that “there’s a hunger or a thirst for information that I do not think will be satisfied by the review of these documents.”
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett, Michael Gold and Mike Baker
item.media:credit: J. Scott Applewhite/Associated Press
item.media:description: Todd Blanche, the deputy attorney general, addressed reporters after the Justice Department released more Epstein files.

item.title: Trump Names ‘Data Nerd’ to Lead Labor Statistics Agency
item.description: The decision to nominate Brett Matsumoto, a career government economist, came six months after the president fired the previous commissioner.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump fired the last Bureau of Labor Statistics commissioner because he said the monthly jobs report numbers had been “rigged.”

item.title: Trump Officials Move to Double Number of H-2B Guest Visas This Year
item.description: It was a rare move by the Trump administration to expand a foreign worker program, amid a sweeping effort to drastically cut immigration.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Giorgio Viera/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A landscaper working outside Mar-a-Lago, President Trump’s private club and residence, in Palm Beach, Fla., in 2022. Mr. Trump has used the H-2B visa program to hire cooks, housekeepers and waiters at his properties.

item.title: Trump Called for ‘De-Escalation’ in Minneapolis. It Didn’t Last Long.
item.description: President Trump has offered dueling messages on the crisis in Minneapolis, part of a pattern of dialing back his rhetoric only to change again if the political winds are shifting.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump in the Oval Office on Friday.

item.title: Epstein Offered Prince Andrew a Meeting With a Russian Woman, Emails Show
item.description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor was stripped of his royal titles last year after new disclosures showed the extent of his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin
item.media:credit: Toby Melville/Reuters
item.media:description: Britain’s former Prince Andrew at the Sandringham estate in England in 2022.

item.title: U.N. Says It’s in Danger of Financial Collapse Because of Members’ Unpaid Dues
item.description: The world body warned it would run out of money by July and have to close its New York headquarters if countries, namely the United States, did not pay annual dues that amount to billions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: The General Assembly in September. The U.N. secretary general, António Guterres, sent a letter to the ambassadors of all 196 member states on Thursday saying, “I cannot overstate the urgency of the situation we now face.”

item.title: What to Know About the ‘Abortion Clinic’ Law Being Used to Charge Don Lemon
item.description: The Trump administration used a federal law prohibiting blockades of abortion clinics and places of worship to charge Mr. Lemon and others in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Madeleine Hordinski for The New York Times
item.media:description: An anti-abortion protest outside a women’s health clinic in Bristol, Va., in 2023. The Trump administration has repurposed a 1994 law that was used to shield women’s health clinics from disruptive blockades.

item.title: Senate Passes Deal to Fund Government and Negotiate ICE Limits
item.description: Democrats agreed to fund the Department of Homeland Security for two weeks while they negotiate with President Trump on restricting his immigration crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson and Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally in Minneapolis on Friday. The Senate passed a spending package to continue funding the Department of Homeland Security for two weeks while Democrats negotiate with President Trump on restrictions to the administration’s immigration enforcement measures.

item.title: Judge Weighs Trump’s Removal of Slavery Markers From George Washington’s House
item.description: The administration has ordered that further changes be made to Independence National Historical Park, according to internal National Park Service documents obtained by The New York Times
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz and Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Rachel Wisniewski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Blank walls where signs about slavery were removed from Independence National Historical Park in Philadelphia last week.

item.title: ICE Expands Power of Agents to Arrest People Without Warrants
item.description: An internal memo changed the standard from whether people are unlikely to show up for hearings to whether they could leave the scene.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents attempted to raid a home in Minneapolis earlier this week.

item.title: Trump’s Immigration Push Fractures Republican Party
item.description: The party was mostly unified on the issue not long ago, but splinters are everywhere now.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis last week.

item.title: Trump’s Lawsuit Against I.R.S. Creates ‘Enormous Conflict of Interest’
item.description: The president is demanding that the federal government pay him at least $10 billion over the unauthorized disclosure of his tax returns during his first term.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump created what legal experts called an unparalleled situation of federal agencies facing a lawsuit from the head of the executive branch.

item.title: Emails Show Warm Relationship Between Epstein and Richard Branson
item.description: The two men’s relationship was known, and a photo of Mr. Branson had been on display in Mr. Epstein’s Upper East Side townhouse.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: U.S. Justice Department
item.media:description: Richard Branson, left, and Jeffrey Epstein in an undated image released by the Justice Department in December.

item.title: 6 Takeaways from ‘Melania,’ the Melania Trump Documentary
item.description: The film, which counts Melania Trump as a producer, touches on her immigrant roots, her love for her mother and her style, but there are few revelations.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik

item.title: Some Republicans Lament the Spending Deal Trump Has Blessed
item.description: Hard-right Republicans have criticized an agreement they see as capitulating to Democrats on their party’s strongest issue: immigration.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, speaking to reporters at the Capitol on Friday.

item.title: Hotel Owners and Workers, Tell Us How You’re Feeling
item.description: With hotels increasingly caught between the federal government’s immigration crackdown and protests against ICE, we want to hear how it’s affecting you.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Adam Gray/Associated Press
item.media:description: A “no sleep” protest against the federal immigration crackdown at a Hilton-affiliated hotel in Minneapolis this month.

item.title: Trump Moves to Cut All Oil to Cuba as U.S. Targets Its Government
item.description: President Trump’s threat to impose tariffs on any country that delivers oil to Cuba appeared to be directed largely at Mexico, the only nation that has sent any meaningful fuel shipments to the island.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Yamil Lage/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The last shipment of oil to Cuba, from Mexico, arrived on Jan. 9, an analyst said.

item.title: Justice Dept. Opens Civil Rights Inquiry Into Killing of Alex Pretti
item.description: The announcement marked a significant reversal in the department’s approach to Mr. Pretti’s killing.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for Alex Pretti, an intensive care nurse who was killed in Minneapolis by federal immigration agents.

item.title: Stock Market Takes Kevin Warsh’s Fed Nomination in Stride
item.description: Stock and bond markets were unfazed by Kevin Warsh’s nomination as the next Fed chair, with the S&P 500 lower on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: Is the ‘Influencer Right’ at Odds With Trump Over Minnesota?
item.description: A vocal group of Trump supporters broke with the president when he appeared to backpedal on his immigration crackdown in Minneapolis. Is it a rift, or just a passing mood?
item.dc:creator: Nathan Taylor Pemberton
item.media:credit: From left, Jason Andrew for The New York Times; Jim Watson/AFP — Getty Images; Jason Davis/Getty Images; John Locher/Associated Press; Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Stephen K. Bannon, Nick Sortor, Matt Walsh, Andrew Kolvet and Nicholas Fuentes, who criticized President Trump after he appeared to temper his immigration crackdown in Minneapolis.

item.title: Who Is Kevin Warsh, Trump’s Pick to Lead the Fed?
item.description: The president’s choice to lead the Federal Reserve is a financier and former governor of the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember and Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alastair Grant
item.media:description: Kevin M. Warsh is President Trump’s nominee to be chairman of the Federal Reserve.

item.title: California Crypto Billionaires Plan to Spend Tens of Millions on Moderate Candidates
item.description: Chris Larsen and Tim Draper, two outspoken Silicon Valley leaders, are planning to spend tens of millions of dollars to elect moderate state lawmakers this year.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer

item.title: Trump Repeats Claims Against Alex Pretti, Casting Slain Nurse as ‘Agitator’
item.description: After videos resurfaced showing a confrontation between Mr. Pretti and federal agents 11 days before officers fatally shot him, President Trump again sought to cast blame on him.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump repeated claims against Alex Pretti, the nurse who was fatally shot by federal agents in Minneapolis, in a social media post on Friday.

item.title: Trump Picks Kevin Warsh as Next Fed Chair
item.description: If confirmed by the Senate, Kevin M. Warsh, a former governor at the central bank, will replace Jerome H. Powell, whose term as chair ends in May.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith, Tony Romm and Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/Bloomberg
item.media:description: Kevin M. Warsh, a former Federal Reserve governor, was also a front-runner to lead the central bank during President Trump’s first term.

item.title: Chevron Points to Venezuela’s Promise as Big Oil Earnings Fall
item.description: The two largest U.S. oil companies, Chevron and Exxon Mobil, reported their lowest annual profits in years.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Micah Green for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Chevron refinery in Pascagoula, Miss.

item.title: F.B.I. Search in Georgia Shows Trump’s Willingness to Pursue 2020 Grievances
item.description: The search might also be a harbinger of things to come, signaling the president’s disposition to use the powers of law enforcement to intervene in election matters as the 2026 midterms approach.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Nick Corasaniti, Julian E. Barnes, Alan Feuer and Richard Fausset
item.media:credit: Mike Stewart/Associated Press
item.media:description: Neither the Justice Department nor the F.B.I. would say what prompted the search of the Fulton County elections office near Atlanta on Wednesday. But a county official confirmed the focus was on reviewing ballots from 2020.

item.title: Fact-Checking Trump Officials on Minnesota After Shootings by Federal Agents
item.description: President Trump and top administration officials, in trying to shift blame over two recent shootings, have mounted an array of arguments for the influx of federal agents.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathered on Wednesday at a candlelight vigil at the site of the killing of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis.

item.title: For Some Americans, the End of Obamacare Subsidies Means Falling Off a Financial Cliff
item.description: Earning just one dollar more could mean a $10,000 increase in insurance premiums.
item.dc:creator: Irena Hwang, Josh Katz and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Lukoil Gas Station Franchisees Caught in a Fight Between US and Russia
item.description: After the United States imposed sanctions on Russia’s two biggest oil producers, the ripple effects wreaked havoc on business for local franchisees.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images
item.media:description: A Lukoil gas station in New York City. In October, the Treasury Department put sanctions on Lukoil and another Russian oil company, Rosneft.
